Grad Club, a popular outlet for
Hopkins students, shuts down
On October 29, the Grad Club
closed.
Located on the ground floor of
McCoy Hall and known for its
wall murals, the Grad Club was
a popular nightspot where
students could dance to the beat
of local bands, listen to songs
from a jukebox, purchase inexpensive foods and drinks, play
pinball and foosball, and gather
with friends.
Serving the University for
twenty-five years, the club had
been open to all students except
on Friday nights, and its owners
carded students to help the club
comply with the Maryland drinking age law. The Student Activities office was the coordinator
of the club.
Both Grad Club managers
resigned prior to the closing.

Dean of Students Chris Colombo
explained another major reason
for the club's closing. "I think the
problem that we ran into was
basically the time commitment,
especially for graduate students
running the club," he said.
Norma Perez, a former
manager of the Grad Club, attributed the club's closing to
"managerial problems based on
misunderstandings. The roles of
managers and administrators
were not defined, and there was
an incredible amount of work
involved."
Colombo said that graduate
students also need to realize that
the amount of patronage at the
club will determine the club's
success. He added that the administration "is willing to support [the Club] in any way."

Research universities should lead the way in
upgrading the prestige of teaching, which is too
often undervalued on the nation's campuses, according to a report issued this week by the
Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of
Teaching.
Ernest L. Boyer, the foundation's president, says
in a foreword to the report: "Elevating teachers
and teaching to a higher position in the hierarchy
of the academic profession, while sustaining and
enriching the tradition of scholarship and research,
is one of the urgent problems confronting higher
education.
The nation's research universities are in the best
position to lead the effort, he says.
"These institutions not only have acquired a reputation, usually unfairly, for undervaluing teaching, they are at the top of the prestige ladder and
they are most likely to be watched and emulated,"
Mr. Boyer says. The 360-page study—The Academic Life: Small Worlds, Different Worlds—is
based on interviews conducted three years ago with
about 200 faculty members from 16 colleges and
universities. It was written by Burton R. Clark,
a professor of education and sociology at the
University of California at Los Angeles.
The report is the second in two years by the
foundation to describe widespread dissatisfaction
among faculty members.
Among the conclusions in the latest report:

MPromotions are often decided more on seniority than on teaching ability and scholarly merit.
MGood teachers who spend a lot of time with
students are seen by colleagues as having misguided academic goals.
111Movement between sectors of higher education is often difficult, if not impossible.
The report says colleges and universities too
often reward faculty members who have not put
forth enough effort in the classroom.
"The greatest paradox of academic work in
modern America is that most professor*._teach most
of the time, and large proportions of them teach
all the time, but teaching is not the activity most
rewarded by the academic profession nor most
valued by the system at large," Mr. Clark writes.
The increasing use of part-time instructors is
another symptom of the low priority that many institutions place on teaching, the report says. Those
instructors, no matter how knowledgeable, are not
regarded as full members of the campus community and are not compensated as such, it adds.
Hierarchies Condemned
The academic profession is permeated by strict
hierarchies, which rank not only institutions, but
disciplines, faculty positions, and tasks, the report
says. Although such hierarchies are "an affront
to democratic instincts,"they provide an incentive for faculty members and administrators to
work hard, according to the report.

Routing the Shuttle
The security van appears to be wrestling with
a bout of inefficiency. Students are complaining that, not only are phone-in pick-ups taking
far too long, even posted library stops are frequently ignored by shuttle drivers.
All the confusion may be caused by a number
of different factors. The addition of a second
van last year might have led to a disproportionate increase in the number of service
patrons. Perhaps the drivers have been improperly trained in adhering to posted schedules
and boundaries.
In any event, the efforts by last year's Student Council to secure another security van
have been undermined by a drop in the quality
of shuttle service. The real concern is for the
level of security being provided as a result.
The University provides undergrads with virtually no on-campus housing after their
freshman year. Ideally, it should compensate
for this by providing safe and convenient
transportation within the Hopkins area—be it
to a party or MSE.
The reality is that the University's present
ability to provide transportation is limited. Not
everyone can receive door-to-door service all
of the time. Given these limitations, the shuttle service's priority must be security.
The shuttle system responsibly protects its
patrons. However, the University's responsibility extends beyond those who choose to
take the shuttle. Should a lone traveller walk
instead of take the shuttle because the wait is
too great, that traveller, too, is the University's responsibility.
A restructuring of the shuttle service is in
order to try and better accomodate for the safety

of the more students. Perhaps, as they review
the vans' performance over the semester,
security officials will cosider using one of the
vans as a pre-routed mini-bus; it could make
designated stops at various points all the way
up though Charles Village and parts of Roland
Park and Hampden. Groups of travellers,
arguably a large source of the shuttle's inefficiency, might be more inclined to use this
method of transportation. Their danger, should
they have to walk a bit to reach a stop (many
of which could be indoors), is less than that of
the individual.
This would help alleviate the workload of the
other van, which would continue to receive
telephoned pick-ups and library stops. Lone
travellers would continue to use this service.
With the load for this van lessened by the routed
bus, drivers could respond more quickly to
calls—and thereby encourage more students
travelling alone to make use of the shuttle.
The key to the success of this system might
lie with the purchase of another van or even
a mini-bus. In this situation, the bus could make
the pre-routed stops, with one van doing only
library stops and the other accepting phone-in
stops. The recent expenditure on a van should
not deter the University from this additional
purchase, should it be determined useful.
Even with only the two vans, this new
schedule might be more effective than the present system. It would encourage those who use
the service more for convenience to use the
mini-bus, while providing an improved doorto-door service for those who should be concerned for their safety.

Man's Best Friend?
by Brooke A. Ettle
"I was walking along and a
black lab ran up and playfully
jumped on me. It didn't tackle me
or anything. It just jumped," said
freshman Seth Hettena concerning an experience with a loose
dog on campus. "I can see how
people might be bothered by a
dog jumping on them. But it really didn't bother me," he said.
Hettena's incident with the
unleashed dog typifies the experiences of other Hopkins faculty and students who have found
themselves harrassed or even attacked by loose dogs on the
Homewood campus. An increase
in the number of' complaints
against unleashed dt)gs since
1983 caused Campus Security to
adopt the first ever dog policy
at Hopkins in July of 1985.
Simply put, the Homewood
Dog Policy states that all dogs,
while on university property,
"must be licensed, leashed, and
under the control of their owners
at all times." Furthermore, dogs
are not permitted in "common
areas of any university building"
or allowed to "be tied up and left
unattended anywhere on campus
grounds." The policy also addresses the removal of animal excrement, citing the owners

responsible for waste deposited
by their animals.
However, since the adoption of
the dog policy at Homewood in
1985, campus security has fully
enforced the law only four times,
despite the numerous complaints
about uncontrolled dogs, primarily on the Gilman/Upper Quad.
Security remains hesitant to
take action against owners who
permit their dogs to run loose.
"There isn't much we can do
with loose dogs," said Major
Robert Larkin, chief of
Homewood security. Larkin
stressed the difficulty in investigating a complaint against a
loose dog, saying that most loose
dogs are gone once security arrives upon the scene. Larkin added. "We're reluctant to do this
[enforce the dog policy] because
dogs are man's best friend and we
really don't want to do
anything."
Many students find the dog
policy unnecessary for various
reasons. Most freshmen, for example, enjoy seeing dogs loose on
campus and feel that the presence
of the animals enhances the
university atmosphere. "I don't
mind dogs walking around," said
undergraduate Stephen Bretz.
"You could say I communicate
well with dogs." Freshman

Richard Quarles agreed, saying
that he "loves the dogs" and
looks forward to seeing them
around campus.
Other students find the dog
policy unnecessary because it is
not consistently enforced at
Homewood. Hettena claims that
the lax enforcement of the dog
policy simply tells dog owners
that security does not object to
dogs running loose. "If you judge
a law by how well it's enforced,
then there is no leash law at
Hopkins," said Hettena.
Sophomore Jenny Levy, like
other dog owners, allows her bull
mastiff to run loose on campus

grounds only since "no one ever
enforces it [the dog policy]."
Larkin responded to these
charges of insufficient enforcement by stating that Campus
Security indeed is not interested
in enforcing the dog policy. "We
want people who have.dogs to be
aware of this problem," he said,
we don't want to make an issue
of this policy and impound these
dogs. We would rather just have
the owners comply and curb their
dogs themselves." Lai-kin added
that students who see loose dogs
"have every right" to ask the
owner to leash his or her animal.
"If that doesn't work, then they

may call security," he said.
"This is the students' campus and
if we all don't take care of it, it
will go downhill."
Bretz, however, disagreed with
Larkin's attitude toward the
policy. "It's a worthless policy.
Obviously, people just don't give
a damn about it," he said. He
added that since many students
enjoy seeing dogs on campus,
few support the dog policy and
post complaints against the
animals to security. Essentially, students on campus do not see
loose dogs as a threat and
therefore do not actively support
the policy.

Routing the Shuttle
The security van appears to be wrestling with
a bout of inefficiency. Students are complaining that, not only are phone-in pick-ups taking
far too long, even posted library stops are frequently ignored by shuttle drivers.
All the confusion may be caused by a number
of different factors. The addition of a second
van last year might have led to a disproportionate increase in the number of service
patrons. Perhaps the drivers have been improperly trained in adhering to posted schedules
and boundaries.
In any event, the efforts by last year's Student Council to secure another security van
have been undermined by a drop in the quality
of shuttle service. The real concern is for the
level of security being provided as a result.
The University provides undergrads with virtually no on-campus housing after their
freshman year. Ideally, it should compensate
for this by providing safe and convenient
transportation within the Hopkins area—be it
to a party or MSE.
The reality is that the University's present
ability to provide transportation is limited. Not
everyone can receive door-to-door service all
of the time. Given these limitations, the shuttle service's priority must be security.
The shuttle system responsibly protects its
patrons. However, the University's responsibility extends beyond those who choose to
take the shuttle. Should a lone traveller walk
instead of take the shuttle because the wait is
too great, that traveller, too, is the University's responsibility.
A restructuring of the shuttle service is in
order to try and better accomodate for the safety

of the more students. Perhaps, as they review
the vans' performance over the semester,
security officials will cosider using one of the
vans as a pre-routed mini-bus; it could make
designated stops at various points all the way
up though Charles Village and parts of Roland
Park and Hampden. Groups of travellers,
arguably a large source of the shuttle's inefficiency, might be more inclined to use this
method of transportation. Their danger, should
they have to walk a bit to reach a stop (many
of which could be indoors), is less than that of
the individual.
This would help alleviate the workload of the
other van, which would continue to receive
telephoned pick-ups and library stops. Lone
travellers would continue to use this service.
With the load for this van lessened by the routed
bus, drivers could respond more quickly to
calls—and thereby encourage more students
travelling alone to make use of the shuttle.
The key to the success of this system might
lie with the purchase of another van or even
a mini-bus. In this situation, the bus could make
the pre-routed stops, with one van doing only
library stops and the other accepting phone-in
stops. The recent expenditure on a van should
not deter the University from this additional
purchase, should it be determined useful.
Even with only the two vans, this new
schedule might be more effective than the present system. It would encourage those who use
the service more for convenience to use the
mini-bus, while providing an improved doorto-door service for those who should be concerned for their safety.

people might be bothered by a
dog jumping on them. But it really didn't bother me," he said.
Hettena's incident with the
unleashed dog typifies the experiences of other Hopkins faculty and students who have found
themselves harrassed or even attacked by loose dogs on the
Homewood campus. An increase
in the number of' complaints
against unleashed dt)gs since
1983 caused Campus Security to
adopt the first ever dog policy
at Hopkins in July of 1985.
Simply put, the Homewood
Dog Policy states that all dogs,
while on university property,
"must be licensed, leashed, and
under the control of their owners
at all times." Furthermore, dogs
are not permitted in "common
areas of any university building"
or allowed to "be tied up and left
unattended anywhere on campus
grounds." The policy also addresses the removal of animal excrement, citing the owners

responsible for waste deposited
by their animals.

the dog policy at Homewood in
1985, campus security has fully
enforced the law only four times,
despite the numerous complaints
about uncontrolled dogs, primarily on the Gilman/Upper Quad.
Security remains hesitant to
take action against owners who
permit their dogs to run loose.
"There isn't much we can do
with loose dogs," said Major
Robert Larkin, chief of
Homewood security. Larkin
stressed the difficulty in investigating a complaint against a
loose dog, saying that most loose
dogs are gone once security arrives upon the scene. Larkin added. "We're reluctant to do this
[enforce the dog policy] because
dogs are man's best friend and we
really don't want to do
anything."

policy unnecessary for various
reasons. Most freshmen, for example, enjoy seeing dogs loose on

looks forward to seeing them
around campus.

policy unnecessary because it is

the lax enforcement of the dog
policy simply tells dog owners
that security does not object to
dogs running loose. "If you judge
a law by how well it's enforced,

mastiff to run loose on campus

On Saturday, November 7, at
Philadelphia, Pennsylvania,
Senior Tim Marean propelled
himself into the record books
with a first-place finish in the
Middle Atlantic Conference
(MAC) men's cross country
championship in the school's
history. In order to gain the title,
Marean surpassed 22 runners that
had beaten him in previous dual
meets. Head coach James Grogan
stated, "I expected him to catch
four or five of those runners but
not 22 of them."
The race, at Belmont Plate&
Fairmount Park, consisted of
many downhills, a feature that
Marean exploited with his long
strides. The mild and windy
weather conditions on the day of
the meet also contributed to his
success. The critical moment during race came at the three-mile
mark when Marean passed the
two leaders and went on to win.
On his performance through the
season, Marean stated that he
"learned to speed up in the beginning and tried to get in better
shape to avoid the burnoff three
miles into the race." He began
training in mid-summer and has
'peaked at the right time."
Neither Grogan nor Marean

expected a first place finish. "I
was pleasantly shocked," noted
Grogan. "I didn't expect him to
win but to do well."
Marean added, "I really
wasn't planning on winning it."
Running without the pressure of
having to win helped him to relax
and perform well in his race.
When he eventually gained the
lead, his training to respond
under pressure aided his effort to
maintain his lead.
Born in Geneseo, New York,
Tim Marean grew up under conditions that would lead to his
future activity as a runner.
Geneseo provided a locale with
an outdoor environment conducive to running; his family supported and encouraged him. His
father, a runner before running
became fashionable, influenced
Marean into running at age seven.
Serious training began at age thirteen and he ran in his first road
race one year later. Running only track in high school, his exposure to cross country came
when he arrived at Hopkins. He
holds his high school's records in
the mile and two mile. Indications
of future success occurred when
he placed third in the MAC conference as a freshman in the 5000
meter run. At a camp in Fort
Bragg, North Carolina the past

summer, he broke the record for
the one and two-mile runs.
Marean arrived at Johns
Hopkins on an ROTC scholarship.
As a chemistry major, he currently plans to go to medical school.
A warm personality, Marean
credits part of his success to the
support he has received from the
people around him. "The cross
country team has good personalities, always ready to crack
a joke or lend a hand," stated
Marean. "The team was ready at
the finish and carried me off to
the trophy."
Out of the field of 23 teams, the
team finished in eigth place (234
points), rising from last year's
ninth place finish. The team improved steadily through the
season and gained ground on
teams that they had previously
faced this season before the
championship. Scott Baker and
Mark Melia turned in good performances in "beating -people
they shouldn't have beaten." Eric
Espenhorst, Erik Schweitzer,
Mark Melia, Dan Dairaghi, and
Chris Crosby rounded out the
seven Hopkins runners. Teamwise, Haverford finished first(27
pts), followed by Ursinus.(119
pts) and Franklin and Marshall
(125 pts).
On his victory, Marean felt

"astonished" but trained greatly
to reach his goal. Marean explained that he "set a goal of running success and kept working
toward it."
"I expected this [victory] when
I was thirteen but I had problems
with injuries. .1 spent most of
the time waiting to develop. I
consider the talent of runnin as

a gift: I try to achieve as much as
possible with it."
The Jays will compete in the
NCAA regionals in Allentown,
Pennsylvania tomorrow, Saturday, November 14. Marean
hopes to qualify and move on to
the NCAA national meet in
Holland, Michigan.
